The document introduces purchasing cards (PCards) as a company charge card alternative to traditional procurement processes. It mentions they're used in the UK as procurement cards and that employees have to follow policies, with controls like spending limits and merchant restrictions. Regular reviews by independent parties are important for managing the program.

The history section talks about their rise, especially in government, with examples like the DOD. They're used for low-value transactions to cut costs, and there's software to manage them. The A/P (accounts payable) use is growing, replacing checks and automating payments. The 2005 survey shows spending growth and predictions about adoption rates.

Statistics include the increase from $80B to $110B in PCard spending, 43% of e-procurement still via check, and 70% of orgs expected to have a program by 2008. The document also mentions challenges like supplier resistance due to fees and surcharges, and the need for education and support during conversion.

Key concepts: definition, controls, history, growth in A/P, statistics, issues with supplier enablement. I need to condense this into a concise summary. Make sure to mention the main purpose, how they work, their growth, benefits, and challenges. Avoid too many numbers but include the main stats. Highlight the shift to A/P and the issues with suppliers.
</think>

A **purchasing card (PCard)** is a company-issued charge card used to streamline procurement of low-value goods and services, bypassing traditional purchasing processes while allowing organizations to set controls like spending limits and merchant restrictions. Originally adopted to reduce costs and bureaucracy, PCard usage has grown significantly, with applications expanding into accounts payable (A/P) to replace checks and automate payments, driven by cost savings and efficiency. Despite growth, challenges like supplier resistance to card payments—due to fees and surcharges—require education and support to ensure successful implementation. Statistics show PCard spending rising from $80 billion in 2003 to $110 billion by 2005, with over 70% of organizations expected to adopt PCard programs by 2008, highlighting their strategic role in modern procurement.

[S1] Purchasing card


# Purchasing card



A **purchasing card** (also abbreviated as **PCard**, **P-Card**, or **ProCard**) is a form of company charge card that allows goods and services to be procured without using a traditional purchasing process. [S2] In the UK, purchasing cards are usually referred to as **procurement cards.**

Purchasing cards are usually issued to employees who are expected to follow their organization's policies and procedures related to P-Card use, including reviewing and approving transactions according to a set schedule (at least once per month). [S3] The organization can implement a variety of controls for each P-Card; for example, a single-purchase dollar limit, a monthly limit, merchant category code (MCC) restrictions and so on. [S4] In addition, a cardholder's P-Card activity should be reviewed periodically by someone independent of the cardholder. [S5] Regular reviews should be part of an organization's ongoing purchasing card program management efforts. [S6] A variety of factors can contribute to its success or, conversely, its stagnation. [S7] There are common P-card program pitfalls to avoid, with the goal of developing success strategies that can put (or keep) a program on the right path. [S8] ## History

Use of purchasing cards have seen a dramatic rise in recent years with many government organizations now using them to remove “red tape” and reduce costs. [S9] For example, In 2001 the Department of Defense (DOD) had 230,000 cardholders with an annual spend of $6.1 billion. [S10] Organizations typically use purchasing cards to target low-value goods and services, as it offers a mechanism to do these transactions at a significantly lower cost than traditional methods. [S11] There are a variety of software solutions available to help manage purchasing card programs, in particular the electronic statements that are provided by card companies in place of traditional purchase invoices. [S12] Organizations have started to use purchasing cards as a strategic form of payment in accounts payable (A/P), in addition to the traditional high-volume, low-dollar transactions. [S13] Organizations are replacing checks with purchasing cards and automating the payment to the supplier. [S14] This is one of the fastest-growing uses of purchasing cards. [S15] According to the 2005 Purchasing Card Benchmark Survey Results (Palmer and Gupta, 2007), traditional purchasing card transactions below $2,000 grew 1.4% from 2003 to 2005. [S16] The most dynamic growth was in transactions from $2,000 – $10,000 representing a 6.1% growth. [S17] A/P transactions fall within this range and can extend into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. [S18] ### Statistics

According to the 2005 Purchasing Card Benchmark Survey (Palmer and Gupta, 2007):

* PCard spending increased from $80 billion in 2003 to $110 billion in 2005
* 43% of e-procurement transactions are paid via check
* By 2008 over 70% of all organizations will have a PCard program, up from 60% in 2005

The study goes on to discuss moving a purchasing card program to A/P. [S19] “The basic idea is to use the card to settle P.O.-driven transactions, like you would use ACH or check. [S20] The company captures the rebates associated with p-card transactions and sidesteps the work processing check payments involved. [S21] Although these cards currently are not in widespread use, their popularity is growing,”

Susan Avery (2005) states that according to the Aberdeen Group purchasing card benchmark report, best practice purchasing card programs “do not confine” purchasing to the traditional spending of low-dollar, high-transaction goods and services. [S22] These purchases include off-contract, non-traditional, non-purchase orders, ad hoc, and incidental purchasing. [S23] Best practice purchasing card programs expand the purchasing card to the AP department. [S24] ## Issues

A **purchasing card** (also abbreviated as **PCard**, **P-Card**, or **ProCard**) is a form of company charge card that allows goods and services to be procured without using a traditional purchasing process. [S2] In the UK, purchasing cards are usually referred to as **procurement cards.**

Purchasing cards are usually issued to employees who are expected to follow their organization's policies and procedures related to P-Card use, including reviewing and approving transactions according to a set schedule (at least once per month). [S3] The organization can implement a variety of controls for each P-Card; for example, a single-purchase dollar limit, a monthly limit, merchant category code (MCC) restrictions and so on. [S4] In addition, a cardholder's P-Card activity should be reviewed periodically by someone independent of the cardholder. [S5] Regular reviews should be part of an organization's ongoing purchasing card program management efforts. [S6] A variety of factors can contribute to its success or, conversely, its stagnation. [S7] There are common P-card program pitfalls to avoid, with the goal of developing success strategies that can put (or keep) a program on the right path. [S8] ## History

Use of purchasing cards have seen a dramatic rise in recent years with many government organizations now using them to remove “red tape” and reduce costs. [S9] For example, In 2001 the Department of Defense (DOD) had 230,000 cardholders with an annual spend of $6.1 billion. [S10] Organizations typically use purchasing cards to target low-value goods and services, as it offers a mechanism to do these transactions at a significantly lower cost than traditional methods. [S11] There are a variety of software solutions available to help manage purchasing card programs, in particular the electronic statements that are provided by card companies in place of traditional purchase invoices. [S12] Organizations have started to use purchasing cards as a strategic form of payment in accounts payable (A/P), in addition to the traditional high-volume, low-dollar transactions. [S13] Organizations are replacing checks with purchasing cards and automating the payment to the supplier. [S14] This is one of the fastest-growing uses of purchasing cards. [S15] According to the 2005 Purchasing Card Benchmark Survey Results (Palmer and Gupta, 2007), traditional purchasing card transactions below $2,000 grew 1.4% from 2003 to 2005. [S16] The most dynamic growth was in transactions from $2,000 – $10,000 representing a 6.1% growth. [S17] A/P transactions fall within this range and can extend into the hundreds of thousands of dollars. [S18] ### Statistics

According to the 2005 Purchasing Card Benchmark Survey (Palmer and Gupta, 2007):

* PCard spending increased from $80 billion in 2003 to $110 billion in 2005
* 43% of e-procurement transactions are paid via check
* By 2008 over 70% of all organizations will have a PCard program, up from 60% in 2005

The study goes on to discuss moving a purchasing card program to A/P. [S19] “The basic idea is to use the card to settle P.O.-driven transactions, like you would use ACH or check. [S20] The company captures the rebates associated with p-card transactions and sidesteps the work processing check payments involved. [S21] Although these cards currently are not in widespread use, their popularity is growing,”

Susan Avery (2005) states that according to the Aberdeen Group purchasing card benchmark report, best practice purchasing card programs “do not confine” purchasing to the traditional spending of low-dollar, high-transaction goods and services. [S22] These purchases include off-contract, non-traditional, non-purchase orders, ad hoc, and incidental purchasing. [S23] Best practice purchasing card programs expand the purchasing card to the AP department. [S24] ## Issues
